dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So Jerome Powell and the Fed are now looking at two rate hikes by the end of 2023—that's way sooner than they were saying just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Jerome Powell and the Fed are now looking at two rate hikes by the end of twenty twenty three-that's way sooner than they were saying just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid a heated debate in Washington over whether easy monetary policy and unprecedented fiscal stimulus spending is actually hampering the economic recovery, Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday signaled that they are looking ahead to two interest rate hikes by the end of 2023sooner than previously expected but not imminentas signs of inflation continue to rattle markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's all because inflation is really starting to pick up, right? I mean, consumer prices jumped 5% in May—highest in 13 years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's all because inflation is really starting to pick up, right? I mean, consumer prices jumped five percent in May-highest in thirteen years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Prices for consumer goods rose 5% in Maythe highest jump in 13 yearsand producer prices soared a record 6.6% during the same month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But Powell's still calling it transitory, like these price spikes are just part of the reopening chaos. He says they'll fade.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But Powell's still calling it transitory, like these price spikes are just part of the reopening chaos. He says they'll fade.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Officials within the Fed and the Biden Administration have repeatedly argued that price spikes are to be expected as the economy reopens, that those spikes will fade over time as conditions normalize, and Powell on Wednesday emphasized that the central bank would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy if confronted with signs that inflation was moving materially and consistently above the Feds goal of a 2% average over time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, but then you've got critics like Mohamed El-Erian warning that if the Fed waits too long, they might have to slam on the brakes later and cause a recession.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, but then you've got critics like Mohamed El-Erian warning that if the Fed waits too long, they might have to slam on the brakes later and cause a recession.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would, in turn, risk both an economic recession and financial market instability.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the Fed's walking this super fine line—they don't want another "taper tantrum" like in 2013 when markets freaked out over policy shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the Fed's walking this super fine line-they don't want another taper tantrum like in twenty thirteen when markets freaked out over policy shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To avoid spooking investors and damaging financial markets (and avoid the so-called taper tantrum that followed tighter Fed policy after the 2008 financial crisis), the central bank takes pains to give investors plenty of notice before it changes its policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're still buying, what, $120 billion in bonds every month? That's huge. But no clear end date for that program.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're still buying, what, one hundred twenty dollars billion in bonds every month? That's huge. But no clear end date for that program.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The central bank also said it would purchase $700 billion in government debt and continues to buy $120 billion in bonds per month to support that market. In the minutes from its June meeting, the Fed did not specify when it would terminate the bond-buying program.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're emphasizing that the labor market's still down 7.6 million jobs since the pandemic started. They want more progress there before tightening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're emphasizing that the labor market's still down seven point six million jobs since the pandemic started. They want more progress there before tightening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, the Fed said it wants to see more progress in the labor market, which is still down 7.6 million jobs since the onset of the pandemic, before it moves to raise rates and tighten policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like they're trying to balance full employment against rising inflation fears. Not an easy job.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like they're trying to balance full employment against rising inflation fears. Not an easy job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely not. And Powell admitted that bottlenecks and hiring difficulties could make inflation stick around longer than they expect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely not. And Powell admitted that bottlenecks and hiring difficulties could make inflation stick around longer than they expect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the reopening continues, shifts in demand can be large and rapid and bottlenecks, hiring difficulties and other constraints could continue to limit how quickly supply can adjust, raising the possibility that inflation could turn out to be higher and more persistent than we expect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So even though they're talking about 2023 rate hikes, it feels like they're buying time to see how things play out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So even though they're talking about twenty twenty three rate hikes, it feels like they're buying time to see how things play out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. The uncertainty is just massive right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. The uncertainty is just massive right now.

HostB: And they’re still buying, what, $120 billion in bonds every month? That’s huge. But no clear end date for that program.
HostA: Yeah, and they’re emphasizing that the labor market’s still down 7.6 million jobs since the pandemic started. They want more progress there before tightening.
HostB: It’s like they’re trying to balance full employment against rising inflation fears. Not an easy job.
HostA: Definitely not. And Powell admitted that bottlenecks and hiring difficulties could make inflation stick around longer than they expect.
